ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: workbook and audio homework, daily seminar style zoom meetings

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Excellent beginning knowledge of the French language. The course went much further in content than other beginning French language courses I've known.
basic/elementary French grammar, language, and culture

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course had a lot of strengths, good instructor, good texts, and French in Action teaching videos that stood out to me. The only thing that might be improved is the speed at which the students receive feedback, especially on the weekly exams.

strengths were the consistency of the class, coming back day after day helped the material stick. weakness was being online, lost some natural flow of conversation and connection which is important for learning a new language. I also wish we had received feedback on tests more quickly to be able to improve for the next week

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, the course worked well over the completely virtual medium. There were less chances for outside class practice and conversation, but that's a side-effect of the virtual setting. If there was a way to facilitate more conversation practice that'd be great.
watching videos together as a class did not work  too choppy and bad connection, hard to hear both video and teacher at the same time. screen sharing in place of a whiteboard was efficient

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely I would recommend this course! I loved taking it compared to other language course I've taken; and the French In Action video component was very unique and facilitated better learning and conversations.
yes! great intro to French coming from someone who was truly a beginner. considering the circumstances it was enjoyable and I'm sure it would only be better in person
